Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Degassing-Based Constraints on the Dynamics of Submarine Eruptions
Award.AbstractNarration: The dynamics (ascent rate, mass eruption rate, lava flow rate, etc.) of submarine eruptions, which account for roughly 70% of the Earth's annual volcanic activity, are essentially unknown. This research will develop a degassing-based "geospeedometer" (i.e., a method for determining how fast magma moves from its magma chamber to its final resting place on the sea floor). for mid-ocean ridge basalts that will allow quantification of eruption dynamics in Earth's largest volcanic system (i.e., the mid-ocean ridge spreading centers) and help to evaluate how those dynamics impact carbon fluxes from the vast mid-ocean ridge system. A combination of detailed microanalysis of textures and volatiles in lava samples from submarine volcanic lava flows and a unique set of laboratory experiments will be used to quantify the mechanisms and rates of degassing and vesiculation in mid-ocean ridge basalts. A "geospeedometer" will be developed on the basis of those results. This geospeedometer will allow us to understand and measure flow rates of mid-ocean ridge lavas, decompression rates of the eruptions feeding them, and how flow morphologies (sheet flow vs. pillow lava) reflect eruption rate. Analyses will be focused on samples from the well mapped and comprehensively sampled 2011 eruption of Axial Volcano on the Juan de Fuca Ridge off the northwest coast of the US and Canada. Samples from this eruption will be analyzed for degassing via volatile concentrations and vesicle-size distributions of samples collected along the Axial Volcano eruptive fissures and flow paths. A central challenge will be the linking of temerature, depressurization rate, and composition to volatile concentrations and vesicle populations. Thus, a series of laboratory decompression and cooling experiments using natural, CO2-supersaturated, mid-ocean ridge basalts will be undertaken to provide insights and input parameters for model calculations, leading to the quantification of results. the 2011 eruption of Axial Volcano will serve as the test case and be used to refine models of degassing and provide the vehicle for incorporating research reesults into broadly applicable models for submarine volcanic systems. The research will also help improve estimates of carbon flux by evaluating more rigorously and quantitatively the controls on seafloor basalt degassing of CO2. Broader impacts of the research include support of graduate and undergraduate students and engagement of the investigators with K-12 STEM teachers via already plannedteacher training workshops. Research will also be incorporated into courses taught by the investigators and data will be made freely available to the public through NSF-funded data management facilities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported the investigation of exsolution of magmatic gases from magma and lava (degassing) during submarine volcanic eruptions. As magmas ascend from depth along mid-ocean ridges, the decreasing confining pressure results in dissolved magmatic gases (e.g., CO2 and H2O) coming out of solution and forming bubbles. The rates of gas exsolution, bubble formation, and growth depend on the rate at which pressure decreases, the temperature of the magma or lava, and the diffusion rate (speed) of gases through the magma and into the bubbles. Collectively, these processes result in rates of gas loss that are similar to rates of magma ascent and lava emplacement thus providing a useful tool for reconstructing the dynamics of eruptions. As no mid-ocean ridge eruption has been observed, tools to reconstruct eruption dynamics are critical to our understanding of how ridges work. 

This project applied experimental, numerical, and observational methods to develop a greater understanding of the mechanisms of magmatic degassing at mid-ocean ridges.

Experimental studies utilized CO2 supersaturated samples collected at seafloor pressures. The experiments heated the samples to magmatic temperatures and then released pressures in a controlled manner to mimic magma ascent and eruption. A key finding from these studies is that along with the rate of ascent/depressurization, the number density of bubbles (number per unit volume) provide first order controls on how quickly gas can be lost from the magma. Thus, while it has been qualitatively assumed that magma ascent rates at mid-ocean ridges must be rapid in order to preserve an excess of CO2 in the lava, those rates need not be as high as expected if the number of vesicles is small.

Observational studies used an extensive suite of samples from the 2011 eruption of Axial Volcano on the Juan de Fuca ridge to track degassing and dynamics of the eruption. With experimental constraints, a numerical model was constructed that enabled interpretation of degassing times based on dissolved volatile concentrations and number and size of bubbles. With this model, we were able to reconstruct the ascent rates of magma along the eruptive fissure and correlated differences in ascent rate with position relative to the seismically imaged magma storage reservoir. In addition, we were able to track the advance rate of lava flows produced during the eruption for only the second time for a mid-ocean ridge volcanic event.

During the course of study, additional projects emerged that were relevant to the primary goals including. First, we conducted an examination of the stereology methods used to convert 2d vesicle poplutions imaged by standard microscopy to the 3d vesicle populations as imaged by x-ray micro-computed tomography. We evaluated the variety of methods used to convert from 2d to 3d, but more importantly determined that the methods in used to reconstruct the amount of gas in vesicles required revision. With this revision, based largely on the assumed temperature at which vesicles are trapped, we were able to validate the assumption that mid-ocean ridge eruptions are a closed system (i.e., gas lost from the melt is completely trapped in vesicles and not released into the ocean). Second, we found that new bubbles nucleated on micro-crystal including oxides as well as silicates. Previously, it was inferred that oxides were the only crystalline phase that impacted bubble nucleation. This discovery demonstrated that heterogeneous nucleation of vesicles, which is commonly observed in eruptions, likely reflects the crystal load carried by the magma. 

The newfound understanding of magmatic degassing in submarine eruptions from this study, opens up the potential to apply these methods to more seafloor deposits and generate a more complete picture of submarine eruption dynamics. In addition, other applications of degassing have emerged such as using dissolved and exsolved gases to reconstruct magma storage depth and using degassing as a paleobarometer to infer past seafloor vertical motion.

The results of this study were widely distributed through presentations at national and international meetings and through published manuscripts. The project also included the training of graduate and undergraduate students in analytical, numerical, and experimental methods.
